I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 

1. 
to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Secondary Cities Development Project.1 
 
2. 
The project cities—Buon Ma Thuot (Dak Lak province), Ha Tinh (Ha Tinh province), and 
Tam  Ky  (Quang  Nam  province)—are  provincial  capitals  representative  of  Viet  Nam’s  rapidly 
developing  secondary  cities.2 Buon  Ma  Thuot  contributes  one-third  of  Viet  Nam’s  total  coffee 
exports.3 Ha Tinh provides strategic connectivity within the Greater Mekong Subregion.4 Tam Ky 
comprises  the  Chu  Lai  special  economic  zone. 5  Limited  urban  infrastructure,  degraded 
environment  quality,  and  vulnerability  to  storms  and  typhoons  in  the  coastal  cities  constrain 
these  cities’  growth  potential.  The  project  will  finance  urban  environment  improvement 
infrastructure through 11 subprojects.6 These will cover (i) solid waste management (SWM) for 
improved  environmental  quality;  (ii)  urban  road  upgrading  for  improved  connectivity  and 
evacuation  during  disasters;  and  (iii)  completion  of  flood  dikes,  drainage  channels,  and 
regulating  basins  for  flood  protection.  The  project  optimizes  development  impact  by  adding  to 
the flood protection and drainage infrastructure initiated through a previous Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) project for Ha Tinh and Tam Ky.7 Project management skills and mechanisms will 
be  improved  for  integrated  urban  development,  environment  planning,  and  climate  change 
adaptation.  Interventions  for  women,  disadvantaged  groups,  and  community  awareness  have 
been integrated into the project design.  
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

3. 
Core urban growth issues. Viet Nam’s population and economy are rapidly urbanizing 
with a structural shift from agriculture to industry and services, which account for nearly 80% of 
the economy since 2005.8 These sectors are key contributors to urban expansion and the rural 
to  urban  transition.  Although  urban  poverty  is  significantly  reduced,  inequality  in  income  and 
access  to  basic  services  remain.  Natural  disasters  and  climate-induced  impacts  add  to  the 
associated  social,  economic,  and  environment  costs  of  rapid  urbanization,  especially  in  the 
secondary  cities  with  limited  capacity  to  address  consequences  of  rapid  urbanization.9 This  is 
recognized  in  the  Framework  Master  Plan  for  Urban  Development  in  Viet  Nam  to  2025  and

4   Ha Tinh in the north–central region has a population of 94,022 with expected annual growth of 8%.  It is currently

natural river courses, with limited drainage capacity of streams and ponds. 

5   Tam Ky has a population of about 109,000, projected to increase to 150,000 by 2015 with annual growth of 1.15%. 
Currently class III to be upgraded to a class II city by 2015, it is affected by an average of five typhoons each year. 
It has high annual precipitation with average annual rainfall of 3,448 millimeters.

 2 

 

Vision  to  2050.10 The  master  plan  aims  to  achieve  balanced  and  strategic  growth  through  a 
national system of capably managed urban centers, envisaging secondary and tertiary cities as 
development hubs within the provincial context.  Developing provincial capital cities as pilots in 
different  geographic  regions  will  boost  the  local  economy,  balance  regional  development, 
strengthen rural–urban links, and address overcrowding in primary urban centers.   
 
4. 
Improved  climate  resilience  of  infrastructure.  The  challenge  for  Viet  Nam  is  to 
maintain its long-term development prospects by minimizing risks associated with urbanization. 
Adapting  critical  infrastructure  by  building  climate  resilience  in  coastal  and  low-lying  areas  will 
safeguard  vulnerable  populations  and  productive  sectors  of  the  economy,  including  its  natural 
resources.11 The  project responds to  stakeholder priorities for  improving  climate  resilience  and 
environmental quality by (i) upgrading road links for connectivity within the urban areas and as 
conduits for  evacuation during  storms  and  typhoons;  (ii)  completing and upgrading flood  dikes 
and  regulating  basins  for  improved  drainage  and  storm  water  management;  and  (iii)  providing 
an  integrated  SWM  road  map  in  Buon  Ma  Thuot  for  an  improved  urban  environment.  The 
subprojects  will  provide  employment  potential,  including  among  the  urban  poor  and  other 
vulnerable groups. The project will enable the cities to transition into regional economic centers 
with improved resilience and liveability. 
 
5. 
Support  related  policies  and  strategies. The project will catalyze the implementation 
of  Viet Nam’s  overarching  policies  contained  in  the  Socio-Economic  Development  Strategy, 
2011–2020  and  the  Socio-Economic  Development  Plan,  2011–2015. 12 The  Socio-Economic 
Development  Plan,  2011–2015  emphasizes  the  need  to  (i)  use  natural  resources  efficiently, 
(ii) enhance environmental protection, (iii) prevent and limit adverse impacts of natural disasters, 
and (iv) respond effectively to climate change. The selected subprojects are enabled by sector 
policies,  including the  Viet  Nam  National Green Growth Strategy  and the  National  Action  Plan 
on  Climate  Change;  and  key  sector  orientation  plans  related  to  land  drainage  and  flood 
protection,  SWM,  and  roads  infrastructure.13 The  subprojects  comply  with  each  city’s  master 
plan  and  are  aligned  with  ADB’s  policies  and  sector  priorities;  urban  operational  plan,  2012–
2020;  and 
the  Viet  Nam  country  partnership  strategy,  2012–2015,  which  promotes 
comprehensive  socioeconomic  development  in  urban  areas,  fostering  balanced  growth  and 
social  stability. 14  ADB’s  urban  sector  assessment,  strategy,  and  road  map  for  Viet  Nam

Implementation Arrangements 

13. 
Project  management.  The  implementation  arrangements  follow  the  government’s 
decentralization policy for ODA- funded projects and are based on previous ADB projects.21 The 
PMUs  for  Ha  Tinh  and  Tam  Ky  (PCI.QNa)  have  experience  in  implementing  previous  ADB 
projects.  The  provincial  people’s  committee  (PPC)  of  Quang  Nam,  Dak  Lak,  and  Ha  Tinh 
provinces will be the executing agencies. The Quang Nam PPC, as lead executing agency, will 
coordinate  and  liaise  with  national  line  agencies  and  ADB  during  project  implementation.  The 
lead  executing  agency  will  consult  the  Dak  Lak  and  Ha Tinh  PPCs  for  all  decisions  related  to 
procurement  of  international  consultants  for  project  management  and  implementation  support. 
The  city  people’s  committees  (CPCs)  of  Buon  Ma  Thuot,  Ha  Tinh,  and  Tam  Ky,  which  is  the 
Projects  Construction  Investment  Management  Authority  Quang  Nam  (PCI.QNa),  are  the 
implementing agencies or project owners. The PMUs of Tam Ky (PCI.QNa), Ha Tinh, Buon Ma 
Thuot,  and  the  Dak  Lak  Urban  Environmental  Company  (DAKURENCO)  are  the  project 
implementation  units.  Each  PMU  will  include  multidisciplinary  skills  and  implement  its 
subprojects.22 The PCI.QNa is nominated as the coordinating PMU in consensus with the other 
PMU  directors,  executing  agencies,  and  the  Ministry  of  Planning  and  Investment.  It  will  liaise 
with the other PMUs to harmonize project implementation. The PMUs for Ha Tinh and Tam Ky 
(PCI.QNa)  have  experience  implementing  previous ADB  projects (footnote  17).  Each  PPC  will 
provide  oversight  and  decisions  on  the  appointment  of  national  consultants  for  its  PMU.  This

B. 

Economic and Financial  

16. 
Economic  analysis  was  done  for  all  subprojects  with  computation  of  economic  internal 
rate  of  return,  net  present  value,  and  benefit–cost  ratio.  The  base  case  results  indicate  all 
components  are  economically  viable  with  an  estimated  economic  internal  rate  of  return 
exceeding  the  assumed  economic  opportunity  cost  of  capital  of  12%.  Results  ranged  from 
13.5% to 18.3% for urban roads, 15.2% to 17.5% for flood control and drainage, and 18.1% for 
landfill. All subprojects were also viable under adverse scenarios wherein costs were higher or 
benefits lower by 10% than the base case.26 
 
17. 
A  financial  management  assessment  confirmed  that  all  implementing  agencies  have 
sound accounting and financial management capacity. The PMUs have experience in managing 
large  ODA-funded  projects  except  for  the  PMU  of  Buon  Ma  Thuot,  which  will  require  support 
through  the  capacity  development  component.  Based  on  existing  policy,  project  assets  are 
turned  over  to  the  provincial  urban  environmental  companies  (URENCOs),  which  will  operate 
and  maintain  the  assets.27 The  financial  soundness  of  the  URENCOs  was  established.  28 A 
financial  sustainability  analysis  was  conducted  for  all  subprojects  by  city  to  confirm  the 
availability of sufficient counterpart funds. Ha Tinh and Buon Ma Thuot have sufficient funds to 
cover  the  ongoing  O&M  costs  of  all  its  nonrevenue  subprojects.  Increased  funds  to  support 
O&M  responsibilities  for  the  Quang  Nam  URENCO  are  ensured  through  loan  agreement 
assurances.  For  the  SWM  subproject  in  Buon  Ma  Thuot,  the  financial  analysis  confirmed  that 
the proposed solid waste collection tariffs will be sufficient to cover the O&M cost DAKURENCO 
will incur.29

D. 

Poverty and Social 

20. 
The project is categorized as general intervention benefitting the total populations of the 
three  cities  including  the  poor,  women,  ethnic,  and  vulnerable  groups.  Interventions  to reduce 
poverty  and  promote  inclusive  development  will  directly  benefit  affected  groups.  The  social 
impacts  will  be  positive,  contributing  to  better  living  conditions,  welfare,  and  health  of  the 
beneficiaries.  A  summary  poverty  reduction  and  social  strategy  includes measures  to  address 
social impacts and enhance distribution of project benefits.30  
 
21. 
Construction  of  the  flood  management  and  drainage  system  will  protect  the 
beneficiaries, especially the poor and vulnerable households, from possible losses in assets, 
income, and livelihood, and resultant health risks from floods and stagnant storm water. The 
engineered  landfill  and  community  awareness  campaign  will  improve  the  SWM  practice,  to 
increase  the  number  of  households  with  access  to  proper  waste  collection  and  disposal,  in 
turn  improving  health  and  sanitation  conditions.  Road  development  will  improve  connectivity 
and help in evacuation during floods. Subprojects will create employment opportunities, during 
construction and O&M, for local people, especially the poor and vulnerable groups.   
 
22. 
The project is categorized as effective gender mainstreaming, and a gender action plan 
has  been  prepared.  The  gender  action  plan  ensures  (i)  50%  female  participation  in  decision 
making related to planning and design of local urban infrastructure investments; (ii) 35% female 
participation in construction supervision boards; (iii) DAKURENCO employing 25% female staff 
in the  new  SWM facility;  (iv)  50% female  trainees in  training  related to  SWM, flood  protection, 
disaster  risk  reduction  and  management,  and  road  safety;  (v)  30%  target  for  training  of  PMU 
female  staff  on  urban  planning,  environmental  management,  and  financial  management  and 
procurement;  (vi)  1,100  women  from  subproject  areas  are  provided  vocational  training  and 
credit  for  income  generation;  and  (vii)  inclusion  of  sex-disaggregated  data  in  the  project 
performance  management  system,  monitoring,  and  evaluation  indicators,  and  regular  project 
reporting.31 
  
E. 

Safeguards 

23. 
Environment  (category  B).  Initial  environmental  examinations  pertaining  to  the 
subprojects were conducted in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) and 
government  regulations. 32 The  subprojects  will  improve  environment  quality  in  urban  areas 
through  improved  SWM,  drainage,  storm  water  management,  and  area  regeneration;  and  will 
not cause any irreversible environment impacts. Mitigation measures for identified impacts are 
included in the environmental management plan (EMP). Initial costs for implementing the EMPs 
are integrated in the project cost. The EMPs will be updated and finalized at the detailed design 
stage.33 Final  EMPs  will  be  cleared  by  ADB  and  form  part  of  the  contract  bidding  documents. 
Environmental  considerations  during  design  and  allocation  of  sufficient  O&M  budget  will  help 
mitigate adverse impacts during operation. Environmental monitoring during implementation will 
be  ensured.  Endorsements  from  executing  agencies  and  government  environment  clearances

25. 
Indigenous peoples (category C). No ethnic minority household is affected in Tam Ky 
and  Ha  Tinh  subprojects.  In  Buon  Ma  Thuot,  16.4%  of  the  population  belongs  to  an  ethnic 
minority  group  (mainly  Ede)  and  42  households  (223  affected  persons)  of  that  group  will  be 
affected  by  loss  of  agricultural  land  (18  households  affected  by  urban  roads  components  and 
24 households  affected  by  the  landfill  site  in  rural  areas).  The  Ede  have  lived  in  this  ancient 
community for several generations. In the landfill site, the Ede households live in two separate 
hamlets. However, the surveys assessed that they are well integrated with the Kinh majority. All 
42 households own their agricultural land or are considered legal. The 42 households have the 
same  source  and  level  of  income  as  Kinh  and  do  not  require  any  relocation.  The  mitigation 
measures  for  land  acquisition-related  impacts,  including  income restoration  for  the  42 affected 
households,  are  included  in  the  Buon  Ma  Thuot  resettlement  plan.  Hence,  a  separate 
indigenous peoples plan was not required.  
 
26. 
Consultations and disclosure. Resettlement and environment documents, prepared in 
consultation with stakeholders and local communities, are in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard 
Policy  Statement  and  Vietnamese  laws.  In  compliance  with  ADB’s  disclosure  policy,  the 
documents have been posted on the ADB website. A grievance redress mechanism agreed with 
the  executing  agencies  will  facilitate  resolution  of  complaints  on  project  performance.  The 
updated resettlement plans and EMPs will be disclosed after ADB clears detailed design prior to 
contract award.
